review_body: Chosen for proximity to business meeting this hotel is placed a bit out of the way. Very few restaurants in the neighbourhood so too out of the way. The rooms are as small as always in Tokyo, but clean and with what is needed. The staff is very helpful; free flowing soft drinks and beer in the lobby.

Positives include location (convenient to subway, restaurants, several of Tokyo’s best sightseeing spots), view of the city and cost if booked well in advance. Having been pleased with the rooms based on two previous stays this time we were very disappointed with the level of cleanliness of the room, -VERY dusty and a constant sewage smell in the bathroom.

I had stayed here 4 days and have a great impression about the hotel. It's a pure business hotel and one should not expect a typical hotel ambience.The hotel is managed such that almost everything is self sufficient in the rooms.Do not stay at this hotel if you wish to be pampared. It's great place people on business, people on vacations / holiday may have a different impression. Overall good opinion and recommended.

A simple , honest and moderately priced hotel for Aoyama. Good breakfast and good service. Small rooms with few amenities. Ok for a short stay. Location is really good. Very clean. Best for short business trips.

Perfect location, right next to very hipster neighbourhood and metro. Tons of trendy cafes and boutiques around in Harajuku. Small french cafe Citroen around the corner was especially nice for breakfast, good value too. Great views from the room, on 22nd floor. Vast choice of amenities incl. free coffee and beer. Great hot water pressure! It was quite clean, one could chose if to have the bed made up and room cleaned next to towel exchange, but there was tons of very visible dust above the bathroom lamp that stayed there till I cleaned it myself.

What more could you ask for! Service is very good in this quiet, well appointed hotel. The rooms are a good size, clean and you can choose whatever amenities you want at reception. We had a kitchenette and washing machine in our room. Hotel is close to the metro and convenience stores. Wasn't a huge fan of the breakfast but it was optional.

I had an excellent stay here. The room is small but clean, has heating/air con, and my room had a washing machine! The breakfast buffet is fantastic and has a variety of foods. The location is excellent as it is very easy to get to Shinjuku and Shibuya.

Stayed for a week instead of the regular chain hotels. Room was small and clean as expected. Toiletries were available in the lobby. Breakfast wasn’t included and available as extra. Room had microwave and a hot plate with small refrigerator. WiFi was good. Housekeeping needs to be requested with full or partial meaning towel and trash only service by placing magnetic sign outside room door by 11 am. Stayed at the Aoyama location to stay away from busy tourist areas. 1 block from Ginza line station. 24hr supermarket and convenience store within the block.

it is small for western people but its quite, and clean and it teach you how to be organize in small place. people where very nice specially a gentleman in the reception who walked with me to the taxi and took care of all details for my trip to the airport.

Very near Shibuya stations, crossings and the hatchiko statue.(walking distance).Clean room, all you need for a short stay, has own washers and free detergents.comfy bed new linens.However no complimentary water or coffee and tea.

The check-in process went very quickly. The hotel room was very clean but fairly small. The room also comes with washer/dryer and microwave. The hotel is also close to several convenience stores. Another plus was the hotel was near by the metro station.Overall, it was a great stay at the Tokyu Stay Aoyama Premier.

This hotel apartment is located in great location, surrounded by stylist shops and good restaurants. Room size is big compare to standard Japanese hotel. Room Facilities (Small kitchen with kitchenware) is perfect for family group.

Reasonable priced hotel, size is normally small for Tokyo, doesn’t really bother us. Cleaniless is good, free drinks at lobby is superb, everything is well equipped. Very satisfied with overall of this hotel. Location is something that can be a gem for this hotel. 3-4 minutes walk to Ginza Line, can go everywhere, very convenient! Nearby has many eatery, few convenient store and two supermarkets which is a plus!

Starting from a super location, near Gaiemmae metro station to an unprecendented hotel service and the concierge who was extremely motivated to help. The room was a bit tiny for western standards, but pristine and well equipped. Definitely reccomend

First off, I'd recommend the hotel and we'd probably stay there again, but there are opportunities for some improvement.We stayed for 12 nights, went as a couple and booked a superior room.What was really good: The location was excellent. It's not at a Yamanote line station, but you can get around really good with the Ginza Line (and Shibuya is only two stops away). The neighbourhood it's located in is really nice and you can walk to Harajuku in 10-15 minutes.The view from our room (we stayed in the 25th floor) was excellent! You get really spoiled going to bed with the whole city in front of you.The beds are really comfortable. The pillows are ok, but after a day in Tokyo you should be able to sleep well anyways. You have lots of restaurants within minutes from the hotel. Right next to the hotell there is a French place called Citron that's really good for breakfast, lunch and a light dinner and just around the corner you have three convenient stores (one of them is open 24hrs). Cleaning was excellent, really nice!Not so good:You can easily hear people in the hall. Not that it happened that much, but worst case, you hear drunk people talking away in the middle of the night when they get home after a night out. You should be fine if you're a deep sleeper, but I got woken up a lot thanks to this. Same goes for sounds from outside. Again, doesn't happen a lot, but firetrucks, police etc are easy to hear when the alarm goes off. The bathroom has everything you need, shower has great water pressure etc, but its the average plastic cubicle you find in most Japanese non-five star hotels. Overall: I'd definitely stay here again; the price, location, view and the fact that you have a kitchenette and washing machine (that's really easy to use and has a built in dryer) makes all the difference. The room was fairly big in comparison with other hotel rooms we've stayed in, so that was nice too. Have a nice trip!

I stayed at this hotel for two nights when I first arrived in Japan from overseas. I asked for a room above the 20th floor on the southside so I could get a good view which was spectacular. The room was simple but very comfortable. Staff at the front desk were very helpful. There is an area for lounging in the lobby which provides free coffee and beer. There is also an excellent breakfast buffet at a small cost which I highly recommend. And location is fabulous- within minutes to Shibuya crossing by subway 1 stop. I will return to this hotel at the end of my trip and I highly recommend it.

I’ve been many times to Tokyo and decided to try the Tokyu Stay Aoyama Premier Hotel this time based on the positive reviews I could see on internet. And I have to say i’ve been very disappointed.Very nice staff and clean rooms, great location (walking distance to Harajuku commercial streets and restaurants, Omotesando....)But VERY tiny rooms. This is probably the smallest room i’ve ever been proposed. I asked to move to a bigger room, not to become claustrophobic. The staff was very helpful and luckily could offer a bigger room (with an additional cost) as there was some availability. Bathrooms also very small and a bit old fashioned No TV channel in English (even CNN is dubbed in Japanese !)

We stayed here for 4 nights in Tokyo on a recent trip. The location was superb a quick walk to the subway and a 15 minute walk to both Roppongi & Harajuku. The room was very well equipped and clean. Our room had a lovely view and was on a non-smoking floor definitely a plus for us! Staff were so helpful and lovely would definitely come back here again next trip.

We stayed here for 4 nights and were quite happy with the hotel. The location is convenient; close to Omotesando, Aoyama, and a few minutes walk to Gaiemmae subway which goes directly to Ginza. The room is comfortable with kitchenette; microwave, pot, stove. Staff can speak good English, but some are not so friendly and helpful.

The room has fantastic city views & is extremely organised, breakfast is well balanced between Western and Asian food options, the location is excellent - close to public transport and many restaurants and convenience stores, the staff are very helpful and friendly. Thank you for a wonderful stay!

We traveled as a family and booked a twin and single rooms. The rooms were on 21st and 24th floor with amazing view over the city. Both rooms were spotless and great value for a good night sleep: quiet and comfortable beds. We booked twin beds instead of a double bed and got two 120 cm wide beds. Great!The location is very good, short walking distance to G-line metro stops. You can choose what kind of cleaning You need to your room by hanging a tag to Your door bef 11:00 ; if no tag at all, there is no cleaning. We chose full house keeping and got fresh towers daily.The breakfast is served in a restaurant on 2nd floor. It was very moderate, but served it's purpose. If You choose not to have any breakfast included, there is a Starbucks cafe just cross the street. Softdrinks, coffee and beer are freely available at the lobby bar.The hotel was better than I anticipated; there fore I am very happy to my experience and would definitely choose Tokyu Stay Aoyama again if I go back to Tokyo again.

excellent price to value with easy access to public transportation and convenient stores. The room is a bit on the small side, but acceptable for Tokyo standard. It comes with microwave oven, washing-and-dryer machine and small refregrator.

We stayed at the “Residence” and it was fabulous. Clean, well-equipped kitchen with a few grocery stores around. Ideal for travellers who like to cook and prefer eating in from time to time. It is centrally located, close to sub-way and within walking distance from Omote-Sando and Harajuku.

After several visits and review about Tokyu Stay Aoyama, i won't go into full details again. Just keep the basics in mind: this is a great place for those who want to visit Tokyo on a controlled budget and enjoy a prime location. It is very Japanese - read small rooms, so if you wish treat yourself to one of the suites on the top floor, is it more expensive but much better value you can get elsewhere.Also worth stating, the views from the higher floors of the tower are fabulous, on crisp clear days you can watch Fuji San in front of you.Expensive? Deals around 180 euros a night for larger rooms are not unheard ofWorth going? Yep

For the money, this hotel is perhaps one of the best in Tokyo. I've stayed in five star resorts that don't match the level of convenience offered by this property. My rate of approximately US $120 included a wonderfully soft bed, a microwave, fridge, pants press, fantastic split-type AC unit, washer/dryer combo, room safe, flat screen TV, unlimited soft drinks, coffee, juices, and Japanese beer (the latter from 11 am to 9 pm), and other free amenities. The neighborhood is quiet, convenient, and steps away from Omotesando and a 15-20 minute walk to Harajuku. The room was clean, spacious (at least for the price), and extremely well organized. I just can't say enough good things about this wonderful hotel. I will definitely be recommending it to friends and family. Such a tremendous bargain.

It works but oddly. Typical business stay mini apts. Fridge, kettle and cooker in unit but no supplies for anything. Convenience stores close so no great drama. Bathroom a challenge for bigger boned westerners but doable. Horrid squeezy bottle hand wash shampoo etc but again there is a a store near by with all you need. Breakfast sucks and the coffee is awful. Next door is a French cafe - best to go there. Free beer machine in lobby 11am till 9pm so there's a perk. Like so many things in Japan v quirky, functionally efficient but not really a pleasing experience

Good value and what you expect from a typical Japanese business hotel - small, efficient, clean, fast internet, great amenities incl a washing machine and microwave in the room. As with almost all hotels in Japan, English language skills of reception staff is a bit bumpy.Location is fantastic, subway 5 min walk; 10 mins to Omotesando. Lots of shops and restaurants nearby.But the best thing is an absolutely amazing view over the city. On a clear day you even can see Mt. Fuji! Try to book a room on floor 20 or up and facing the south.

Nice hotel in a rather upscale residential neighborhood. Rooms are fairly small but decent, nothing extraordinary. Kitchenette and washing machine in the room. The bathroom looks prefabricated, which is a little weird, but perfectly functional. However, the views over the city from the rooms and the lobby are fantastic. I was able to watch sunrise over Tokyo with Mount Fuji in the distance. Located close to Omotesando, a busy and very trendy shopping area, and not too far from Harajuku. Close to the subway, 2 stops from Shibuya, a few more from Shinjuku. Nice tex-mex restaurant downstairs.

The hotel itself is very close to metro station with plenty convenience stores and dinning places nearby. The lobby lounge also provides unlimited soft drinks and beer. Surprisingly all rooms are equipped with a small kitchenette and a washing machine that are convenient for long stay.

It was just a block away from the metro station (but not the big one, so no lift access). We were quite satisfied to stay but it was not a tourist area. If you are looking for dining place and shopping places then you have to hop on a metro first. Hotel itself nothing to complain about. Completed with washing machine, no need to bring lots of clothes...

I really was very satisfied with my stay. Booked a twin room, had a great view. Included an L shaped sofa and coffee table in the room, nice big TV and kitchenette with microwave. Bathroom was a nice size. For Tokyo standards the room was pretty big. Location was good to about 1km from shibuya shopping area. Nearby within 2 minute walk was McDonald's and a grocery and drug store. Good area felt very safe.Stayed on the 24th floor. Acceptable value for money at $170usd night including taxes. Sadly no breakfast but they did offer free coffee drinks and beer at the lobby where they had fountain machines and vending machines if u wanted to buy bottled water. Staff were friendly and always helped. however they never offered Bell boy service and there's no one downstairs to call a taxi for you (although we never waited more than 5 minutes for a taxi). Tip: we took a taxi to Cerulean hotel where we caught the airport bus to Haneda. That was the easiest way for us to get to the airport. Very convenient.

Great Location (walkable to Shibuya and Shopping street). The rooms are located from 14 floor and higher of a highrise so it has a pretty nice view. I am very satisfied with the small facilities they provided in the room (washing machine, detergent, Pant's press iron and all the cosmetic and toiletries free of charge. It is pricey for the NYE but otherwise it is totally worth it.

The area is good BUT the rooms are not only very small which is normal in Tokyo but this is very very small and not clean and it smells. Better find another Hotel. I am just checked in and looking for another option in town now.

we booked 3 double rooms the bed was really small and the room too the reception was so nice and helpful to show us the room and try to helped us the room was prepared well with most of important thinks we stay for 5 nights it has good restaurant around and near metro station were Ginza line to cover most important places

I stayed here for 2nights during 14-16September16. Sorry for late review. Anyway, I appreciate to your hotel staffs, (reception and housekeeping) they are really good service-minded and smiling welcome. the reception desk has on top floor, it has good and not busy. Especially, housekeeping staff who never seen them during stay. They made up my room when I went outside. Even this hotel may be not 5stars hotel but standard service is more high expectation. I hope to see you guys again in really soon.

The hotel is in a commercial yet quiet area. Everything you need is just minutes away. Close to Gaienmae station, and in walking distance to Omotesando or Shibuya. The hotel is undergoing a renovation process, some rooms do look tired, so this does not come too early. However, during my stay there was disruption due to this, especially no noise. As this hotel caters to individuals and not tour groups it is usually really quiet. Rooms are small and there is no closet or even space to open a big suitcase flat on the floor-but then again this is Tokyo. What I love is the big window-it gives a feeling of space. The mini-kitchen including fridge is great and if you stay for a bit longer there is even a washing machine. The staff is friendly but they do not have any kind of customer loyalty programme or even recognizing it when you are coming back the 20th time...In conclusion: location, the big window and small kitchen make all the difference for me. Since this hotel opened 10 years ago I am always going back to it as it serves my business travel needs well.

The room was small but I found that to be the case everywhere I went in Japan. The view was absolutely beautiful...I could even see Mt. Fuji in the distance! There is also a great view down into a graveyard from the reception area. The staff was very kind, patient and helpful. I would definitely stay here again.

The best part of hotel is location and being near to Tokyo 's famous metro station commutation is not an issue.The room are not large still you can manage due to efficient use of space.View and cleanliness is remarkable. Downside is there is only one english channel on TV . There is 24 hour store and lot of eateries near hotel over all a good experience.

This is the worst hotel in Tokyo, extremely small room, did not understand my needs, even there werent a duty manager in the reception to listen and understand my needs.They gave us a one bedroom apartment instead a two beds. When we asked for a separate bed, they told us to there were already two beds which were rediclously very close toneach other. Does not complete an apartment facilities. Immdeiately checked out and moved to another hotel. Do not even try it!

We spent one week there in April (2 adults + 2 kids) and had two of their largest rooms - prettty big for Japan including kitchen and washing machine. Location is really good, close to interesting areas and 2 minutes walk from the G-line (key subway line). We were at the 25st floor and the view is amazing. Did not try the breakfast/food. Service and cleaning are Japanese ie. perfect!

We stayed at Tokyu Stay Aoyama for 5 days. It's in a great part of Tokyo. Easy to get anywhere from there. The hotel has long term stay as well. The room was not enormous but you don't expect a huge room in Tokyo. It was pristine though and that's definitely a plus. It was reasonable priced and I'd definitely recommend it. There are limited cooked facilities and a fridge.

Stayed here for a week each time over the past 2 years, and i must say that this is a pretty homely hotel away from home.Although the room isnt exactly large, the room is well furnished: Microwave oven, washing machine, refrigerator, bathtub, pant press, and a nice queen size bed.The hotel is located 2-3 mins from Gaien-mae station and is in a rather upscale district. There are quite a number of popular japanese restaurants around this area, but it might be pretty difficult to identify them if you do not speak japanese.There are a few super market nearby, and even one that is 24 hrs. Great location overall, and definitely recommended for business travel.

This was a pleasant hotel. The rooms were fairly well sized, with a washer, and microwave in the room. The staff were friendly and helpful...although not very good in English. Don't bother with the hotel breakfast....you are better off going across the street to the Starbucks.All in all a pretty good hotel...clean and quiet.

Used for a short stay and recommend to me by a friend. Has everything my friend and I needed, plus right next to the subway, beautiful view of the city, attractions near by, and some places to grab a quick bite. Highly recommend to travelers looking for a well equipped hotel in a great location.

The room was comfortable, spacious, clean and with all amenities (including washer/dryer). Staff is friendly and helpful and hotel location is great - in Aoyama, near the metro, a few stops from Tokyo main station.There are plenty of shops, cafes and entertainment in the neighbourhood.

After a monumental upheaval at a sister-hotel (the Tokyu Stay Shinjuku), where the power went out and all guests were relocated, I was dispatched to the Aoya version of the brand and it did very nicely. The room was of adequate size and amenities were great. I can't really speak of the price because being a refugee of Shinjuku this was just a straight swap (as long as Agoda doesn't attempt to bill for the difference, peace will reign between us). Initially I wanted to be in the thick of the noise and bustle that is Shinjuku but all that was within easy reach via Giaenmae (Ginza line) station, a couple of minutes' walk away. In retrospect, it was good to reach some peace at the end of each day.The desk staff were very personable and friendly with varying English skills; even so, there were no arduous transactions. I wouldn't hesitate to stay here again, provided prices were in the mid-range. Overall it was a pleasant experience.

Booked through Booking.com. Had a single room which came with everything you'll need for a short stay, washing machine for dirty laundry, microwave, etc. There's a kettle for hot water and a Seijo Ishii convenience store just a few minutes away. The room size was just enough for sleeping and doing a bit of work at the desk. Front desk people were efficient and spoke good English. Only 3 minutes walk from Gaienmae Exit #1A

The Tokyu Stay Aoyama Premier was recommended to me by a Japanese colleague and I was not disappointed during my five-day work trip. As has been noted by other Trip Advisor reviewers, this is a proper Japanese-style business hotel - rooms are hardly spacious by western standards but are definitely compact, clean, WiFi-friendly and exquisitely well organized, especially considering the small room size. Fits one perfectly. I was in a double on the 19th floor with a lovely view of Mount Fuji and easy access to Gaienmae and Omotesando Metro stations. Thankfully the hotel is a bit removed from the noise of Shibuya, Shinjuku and Roppongi but still walkable to each of these neighborhoods. A number of upscale cafes, restaurants and boutiques are accessible on the ground and second-floor courtyard surrounding the hotel, including the cafe which offers a standard but delicious Japanese breakfast for hotel guests. Would definitely stay here again.

Near to Tokyo Metro Gaienmae station, groceries, restaurants, quiet area. Room just the right size for a solo traveller and laundry machine inside the room is a big bonus. My room did not have that musty smell that old hotels have.

The double twin room was comfortable, in fact large twin beds, fairly spacious, clean and with all amenities. Had two good nights sleep. Helpful staff, and great location in Aoyama, near the metro, so a few stops from Tokyo main station. Plenty of shops, cafes and entertainment. A couple of stops away from Shibuya, another great place to visit, and also catch the express train back to Narita airport.

This is my second stay at this hotel. During both stays, Tokyo has experienced heavy rains due to passing typhoons. I'm not sure the hotel wants me back!I like staying at this hotel, although I have to say I am very disappointed at the service I experienced during this stay. Otherwise, the hotel has a lot to offer. In my opinion, the location is GREAT. Right outside the door are plenty of dining options,and great shopping is not far distant. Omotesando is definitely walkable, and if you are up to it, so is Shibuya. Roppongi is perhaps a bit of a further walk but doable. Jingu Stadium is a ten minute walk. I also like that this hotel has in room combination washer / dryers. This hotel was one of the first in this price range that I am aware of to offer in room wi-fi, and it works well / fast. Breakfast was included in my room rate in 2013, but this time cost 1200 yen. Breakfast is in a third party establishment in the same building. Choices are acceptable and sufficient, but not up to the number of choices at other Japanese hotels at which I have stayed. Rooms are small, but reasonably efficiently laid out. Before booking, check the hotel website for room options - there are a wide range of choices.Towels are thin, thin, thin. Cheap thin. Also worth noting: If you turn off the air conditioning, you can hear a lot of exterior traffic noise, including what I believe are passing trains on the underground Ginza Line. However, my main beef with this stay was with the service. I was at the hotel two nights during this stay. The day between the two nights was rainy all day. I was out of the hotel from about 10 am to 12:30 pm, but my room was not cleaned until close to 3:00 pm. The young man who cleaned my room was clearly not happy I was in the room and kept pushing the desk chair in which I was sitting and my things around. Yes, I realize it would have been easier for him if I was not in the room, and yes I realize the room is small. But I am the customer. Without customers, he doesn't have a job.The other service disappointment was asking for delayed checkout. I was switching hotels in Tokyo to join a tour group and could not check in to the other hotel until 3 pm. Check out at the Tokyu Stay Aoyama Premier was 11:00 am. Again, the day featured hard rain. Respecting that the hotel needed to clean rooms for incoming guests, I asked only for a noon departure. I don't know if there was a language barrier or what, but the response by the front desk clerk was to point to 11:00 am on his watch. This hotel has a lot to offer in terms of location and in room amenities for the price range. However, with the service I experienced this time, I will at least explore other options if returning to Tokyo.

Accommodation in Tokyo never comes cheap, so the stay is not a bargain, but not as overpriced as some others. Layout is nice and convenient. But it doesn't help if you cannot sleep because of the noise from the open air bar opposite. And, nothing wrong in itself, the more drunk people get, the louder they get, too. And this at 1, 2, 3, even 4 a.m. We tried to join them, but I just cannot go out 4 nights a week until 4 in the morning. There is no law which can stop them, police says.

I stayed at this hotel for 5 days. In fact it was good hotel according to the service, location and the price. Their breakfast is not that much. The staff were helpful. The location was near the fastion street and next to the metro station. If you care about how much to pay, this hotel is great for you.

I'd been to Tokyo several times and decided to stay away from the usual touristy zones. Our choice was Tokyu Stay Aoyama Premier and it fulfilled our expectations. This hotel's not in the heart of the action (though Shibuya etc are a short metro ride away). Instead you'll find a quiet surroundings filled with upscale boutiques and eateries. Around the corner is an excellent curry joint which plays live music in the evenings, unfortunately I cannot remember the name at the moment. There are several cafes a short stroll away where you can have a western breakfast and people watch (lots of well-heeled ladies who lunch types). Transportation is a breeze by the underground. The rooms are small, as you'd expect in Tokyo, but impeccably clean. The lobby area is a bit dreary, but you wouldn't spend much time there as check-in/checking out was a breeze. As the hotel is set on the upper floors of an (office?) building, you often share an elevator with locals. We would definitely stay again.

We stayed at the Tokyu Stay Aoyama Premier for 4 nights this July 2015. The room size was just adequate. You can walk around inside the room without bumping into your companion - not like the other Bento Box rooms we've tried out in Japan. Quality of sleep was perfect. Beddings were very comfortable. The air conditioning was very very strong and loved it especially during that time when it was hot in Tokyo. It's also a first for me to get a room with a washer/dryer, a microwave and an electric stove. We've used the washer/dryer a couple of times as we had lots of laundry from our trip in Hokkaido. The location is nice. Lots of restaurants in the area. We've walk to Roppongi Hills and Harajuko. The Tokyo Metro is also very close by.Can't comment of the restaurant as I'm always out to wander around.I really liked this Hotel and it's location that I'm already planning to go back here for a longer stay.

I stayed here with my wife and 1 year old daughter in July. We chose it for its proximity to a wedding we were attending. Personally, I thought there was very little to distinguish this hotel from multitudes of other Tokyo hotels. Tokyo hotels I have stayed in have all been small (you have to jump over your luggage to get out the door). This one does have a laundry machine INSIDE the room however, which was a new experience for me. We did not end up using it, because we stayed only one night, but that could be very convenient for some travelers and deserves a recommmendation. Traveling with a baby especially, we saw the value of this. I take away one star from my rating however because, due to our flight arrival time, we needed to check in around 630am. For this, we were charged one whole extra nights stay. Previously, we stayed at a different Tokyo hotel (Hotel Wing Ikebukuro) and were able to check in early with no extra fee. I think in a city like Tokyo, with so many international arrivals, it would be helpful to travelers to have a less strict check-in policy. Additionally, the lobby staff told us upon check-in that the room cleaning time was at 2pm, and asked us if that was OK. We just stared dumbfounded and requested to skip the "cleaning" of the room which we had not even spent the night in yet.In addition to the laundry machine in the room, the hotel boasts some kind of kitchenette, which is basically a microwave, sink, and some assorted utensils. This came handy for us in cleaning baby bottles, but i don't imagine cooking a meal in there, and the hotel rules beg guests not to use "excessive oil" when cooking food in the rooms. Fortunately, during our stay, we did not detect the smell of frying foods anywhere in the hotel.The neighborhood is very walkable, with restaurants, a Starbucks, and several supermarkets and convenience stores nearby. The shower had good water pressure and felt refreshing. The rooms are quiet and clean.For 1100yen/person, there was a cafe on the 2nd Floor offering a nice breakfast buffet of salad, ham, salmon, rice, pastry, juice, and coffee that was very convenient. Overall, I would recommend if you don't need an early check in.

We stayed here for 2 nights for a break during our ski trip. I chose to stay here because they have a mini kitchen and a combo washing/dryer machine, now that's handy to wash all of our ski clothes!The location is close to the famous Omotesando fashion street and around the corner from the Gaiemmae Station on the Ginza Line. If you are an art lover, you are in the right precinct as there are numerous art galleries around, of all sizes. My favourite is the Watari-um Museum of Contemporary Art, just down the road. Amazing views!!! Our room was on the 25th floor and we could we Mt Fuji in the distance when the sky was clear.All in all, it was luxury, convenience and private views all in one hotel room. We will stay here again in a heartbeat.

The point I chose this semi-apartment type hotel was that:They have laundry systemThey have mini kitchenConveniently located,just a minute from nearby sub station.Close to all terminal like shibuya,Ginza,Tokyo station,and Shinjuku.Although the space was a bit tiny for two,We can't complain because the price was cheaper than other nearby hotels.And whenever I need something ,it's a second walk to drug store,mini super market.Clean up room service was offered every day for less than 7nigts stay.Their laundry system worked very well,I love Japanese electric equipments!Definitely recommend all the travelers who want to save money/stay conveniently.

Tokyu Stay Aoyama has been one of my main addresses in Tokyo for years. Obviously, if you seek large, European (or American) standards room, this is NOT the place to come. It is a real Japanese business hotel. What makes it worth the visit? price and location.True to other comments, rooms are small, can not be considered "designed" and bathroom is a plastic cubicle. The only point is that price wise it is much more affordable that the neighbors hotels and view, if you get a room in a high floor, is really fabulous. Having gone there loads of times, i understand some reviews. Just need to be aware that hotels in Tokyo come pricey, and that Japanese standards are not the same as ours in terms of room size and what is comfortable or not.

Situated in fashionable and central Aoyama, the hotel rooms are a little like mini studio apartments. This hotel is perfect if you want a convenient location. It is a five minute walk to Gaienmae station and the Ginza subway line (the original line). It's ten minutes walk to highly fashionable Ometsando and its station housing the Ginza, Chiyoda and Hanzomon and Den Entoshi lines. Walk another ten minutes to Harajuku, Yoyogi Park and Meiji Shrine ... or ten minutes to young Shibuya. It's ten minutes walk to Aoyama itchome station and 15 minutes to the Emperial Palace gardens. Its also ten minutes walk to Roppongi. You can't go wrong with this hotel. The only complaint I have is their 1500 check-in policy. Normally hotels will allow you to check in early if your room is ready but not here!!!! >:-( You must be prepared for this if you have a long haul flight.

The hotel provides a perfect location just next to Gaianmae metro stop. Expect decent sized bedrooms, with enough facilities to cover all your expectations from what would be a 4 star hotel category. The views from the reception area great, so are the room views, especially if you ask for a high floor. Bathroom is small but enough to keep you comfortable.The hotel is next to trendy Omotesando area, full of trendy shops, cafes and restaurants. Very recommendable to explore this area, really cool. for a good value for money hotel in Tokyo, I think this one is just perfect.

I chose this hotel since my mom and I wanted a change from the full-service/luxury hotels we usually stay in. I've been curious about the Tokyu Stay hotels since they seemed to be spacious by Japanese standards and were moderately-priced as well as being in a good location. I was choosing between Aoyama Premier and the Yotsuya one, but in the end chose this one. We got a twin room on the 24th floor which we found quite roomy. The closet was small but we didn't have a lot with us so it was no problem. The bathroom was a little small but very clean with an automated toilet and lots of toiletries which were replenished daily. There was a washing machine and dryer and a cooking plate (didn't use those) and a refrigerator which we filled up with our own snacks and drinks. The beds were comfortable and my mom was able to sleep most of her jet lag off, which was a good thing. The only problem we had with the room was the remote control for the airconditioning - it really took time to adjust the temperature to the desired function and setting. It was either a bit too warm or freezing cold. We had to ask the staff to check it and change the battery of the remote control, but after that it seemed to work fine.Breakfast was at Lanikai Cafe on the second floor, for 1200 yen per person. It was not lavish by any means but it was complete and gave us a good start to our day. We also tried the Indian restaurant Ahilya in the row of restaurants downstairs, which was also good. All in all we were very satisfied and are looking forward to coming back.TIP: There are two 24-hour supermarkets within a 1-2 minute walk from the hotel (Aoyama Peacock and Seijo Ishii) where you can pick up prepared meals, snacks, drinks and anything else you need. We just loved this fact about the hotel. There's also a Starbucks and a Subway on the way to Gaien-mae Station, as well as a convenience store.

Average hotel with comparative small rooms, but the service is good with pretty good breakfast menu. In house bar is also good. Some room face the Tokyo Tower.Good restaurants available in very close vicinity.
user_location: National Capital Territory of Delhi, India
user_name:
JainForJains
National Capital Territory of Delhi, India

review_body: I had been staying for a month. it is lovely atmosphere and very spacious. the near by places are also good. it is very clean and by metro station is an advantage. from the reception lobby we can see the beautiful view of the Minato-ku

I'm totally impressed with this hotel! The location is obviously great, but I love how spacious and clean the rooms are, all with excellent staff! (Well - spacious by Japanese terms.) The free wifi in all rooms (even good reception in the lobby & restaurant) is a really nice bonus. I would stay here again and highly recommend it.

It was a business trip and I stayed here for more than 2 months. They have apartments and hotel rooms in the same building. Located in prime locality and at walking distance from places like Omotesando, Shibuya Aoyama and at close proximity from Roppongi, Akasaka, Ginza etc.theyThis is a nice place with different cuisines available just below the hotel. They have a Indian restaurant, American, Chinese French and even a Godiva chocolate store in the same building.Take a train in Ginza line and get down at Gaienmae station exit 1A and walk straight until you see Aoyama Passage on the left. Take left follow and exit. On the left is the Tokyu Stay building. This is a secure hotel with access cards to enter the building and room. They have high speed internet at room, unlimited free WiFi and other utilities. They have English channels in the TV. Yaay! Sports channel too because of which I never missed premier league matches.One of the best apartment hotels to stay at if you are in Central Tokyo area.The apartment had a small kitchen with refrigerator, microwave, otg, steam iron, washer and dryer, television, utensils, locker,wardrobe. There is a lounge opposite to this hotel (crystal lounge). A short walk will take you to Omotesando and shibuya. A walk in the opposite direction will take you to Aoyama.This is one of the best place to stay, not cheap though. Tokyo is never cheap but considering the apartment and facilities along with the locality, this is the good place.

I stayed in the hotel in December 2013. The rooms are not so big but comfortable and very quite. Good breakfast. You have a beautiful view on Tokyo. The hotel is nearest to the underground station and near hotel good restaurants

Great location. Nice clean rooms with all the amenities. Love the peaceful quiet neighborhood though. And if you want the hustle and bustle of the city, 2 train stops and you are in the heart of Shibuya.
user_name:
Stevo M
Petaling Jaya, Wilayah Persekutuan, Malaysia

review_body: The Hotel Tokyo Stay Ayoama Premier was definitely that greatest surprise of our travel, since we were expecting a small room and basic services for the price we paid, we ended up in a quite large and comfortable room (large for Japan standards, much much larger), with two large beds and a fully equipped room that made our life with a baby way easier.  In summary, it was a great stay. The only complaint I have that the Hotel should strongly review is the check in/out policy, since the check in is allowed only after 3pm, and the check out has to be made before 11am, with no late check out option, unless you pay 50% of your rate to stay only 2 extra hours…:PROS- New and modern facilities;- Unusually large rooms for Japan standards;- Lots of restaurants in the boulevard of the Hotel. Many dining options in the surroundings;- Great, just great location in the fancy Ayoma District, in block from the Ayoma.- Very close to the Gaienmae Metro Station (Line G – Ginza)- Fair breakfast;- Really fast and free Wi-Fi all over the Hotel;- Nice staff, English speaking.- Great cleanness- Washing/Drying machine inside the room (great!). Mini-kitchen exceptional…- Great (soft) beds.CONS:- Strange policies for check in (after 3pm) and check out (before 11 am with no flexibility);- TV with no English speaking channels. For extra, you pay apart a pre-paid card to give you access to VOD:- No baby beds, not quite baby friendly.- No coffee maker in the room.- Breakfast has slow reposition of items. They tend to end quickly when is full (between 7:30 and 8:30am). Few options in the breakfast had better in Japan.

I came back to stay another week in this hotel after my good experience a year earlier. A great place to combine business and pleasure, with the trendy shops of Omotesando and Harajuku, popular Meiji-Jinggu park and shrine, and the exquisite art collection at Nezu Museum all in walking distance. The hotel rooms are compact and complete. Breakfast served in the Architect Cafe downstairs is a daily pleasure. Gaienmai subway station is just around the corner with connections to all of Tokyo's attractions.

I stayed in this place for one week whilst on business in Tokyo. It is in a nice neighbourhood with plenty of restaurants and shops around. The subway station is five minutes walk. The hotel is very comfortable and guests are provided with a laundry machine, a microwave and a refrigerator. If you have the chance to be accommodated on the higher floors, you will have a stunning view on the nights.The breakfast is wonderful with Japanese and international foods served together at the choice of the clients.Guest will be happy to have just on the corner of the hotel a passage with several restaurants and cafes in a very beautiful atmosphere. If you like Indian food, try Alhiya, a restaurant in the passage. You won't be disappointed.I would definitely recommend it.

Family of 4 stayed 2 nights in August 2014. We found the TSAP to be a comfortable business class hotel with bonus amenities, including a washing machine in the room (buy detergent from the vending machine in the lobby on 13) and a refrigerator as well as a cook top. We used all and were happy with them. Our room on the 25th (top) floor was compact but clean and efficient, and for the money worth the expense. TSAP is a no-frills business type property and is well kept up with no surprises. The staff were helpful and pleasant. The bonus from our perspective is the location being accessible to Shibuya, Omotesando, Shinjuku, Harajuku, Yoyogi and the Meiji Jingu shrine area. My only reservation is that the ceiling height in the bathrooms is a little short, probably only 6'3" or possibly less which could be inconvenient for very tall travelers.Traveler Notes: There is a very nice supermarket around the corner on Aoyama Dori towards Akasaka as well as a Lawson Station just a little further along if you need to pick up some items. There is also a McDonalds on Aoyama dori in the opposite direction towards Omotesando which is open 24 hours less than a block away.

Very close from Omotesando, 5 minutes walk, so very good location with not expensive price. Each room has a laundry machine, microwave, air cleaner, so very convenient. Room is not big, but I like this hotel because of the location and facilities.

I've stayed at this hotel more than a dozen times now. It is very reasonably priced (about 100 euros per night) for Toyko and has a great location in an upscale part of town. The single rooms are small but clean with modern decor. Plus the rooms have every gadget you might want including washer/dryers, kitchens, and excellent internet. They no longer offer free breakfast and seem inflexible about the 3 pm check-in, but otherwise a good value for a solo business traveler who doesn't need any extras.

The hotel is in Minami-Aoyama, which is a wonderfully elegant and quiet part of Tokyo, nearby Omotesando, with easy access to Shibuya and Shinjuku. Wonderful views since the hotel is located on the 13th floor (lobby) and up of the building. Great breakfast at Architect Cafe. I could go on and on, but this is best value for a great Tokyo experience. Spent 10 days here and will return.

We just spent one week at this hotel which is located in an excellent area of Tokyo. We had a twin room and though it was small by US standards it was large by Japanese standards. We were 25th floor with a huge window looking over half of Tokyo. The room had a small refrigerator and microwave which we used for breakfast every morning, buying supplies at near by convenience stores which are part of the Japanese lifestyle. Easy to buy fruit, yogurt, breads, etc. such places. Room provided dishes and an electric kettle and teabags. Saved money over the $18 breakfast buffet offered by the hotel. The room was serviced every day and kept nice and clean. Free wi-fi, large screen TV with CNN. Our twin room had 2 drawers available to unpack, but the closet was very small, only 4 hangers. All in all this is an excellent reasonable choice for a stay in Tokyo.

This hotel offers great value in an upscale neighborhood. As is typical in Tokyo, the rooms are small but are well organized and equipped with everything you need. The microwave and the washing machine are great additions -- after a week's stay, it was nice to be able to do laundry and pack all clean clothes for the journey back home. The subway station is located a few minutes away, so there is easy access to public transportation (but this is not unusual for almost anywhere in central Tokyo). The hotel is located in an upscale neighborhood in central Tokyo, with very nice shopping and restaurants. By Tokyo standards, however, it is not a particularly "bustling" area -- it seems almost empty in the evening (but by North American or European standards it would probably be busy enough).
user_name:
SoloFemaleTraveler11
New York City, New York

review_body: Stayed on business. Very helpful staff (in English). Rooms are small by north american standards, but generous by Japanese standards. Fantastic location, close to subways, shopping, restaurants, etc. Highly recommended.

I stayed three nights here in March and had a good stay. The room (a semidouble) was perfect for one (tall) man and was well appointed. The staff were very helpful on check in and assisted me on departure booking an airport shuttle. The breakfast (included) was fantastic and there was a good choice of western and Japanese.

Was in Tokyo, where I used to work and live, for my sons wedding. He recommended the hotel for its location and comfort. Whilst the room was not large it did contain a washing machine and microwave oven and a very comfortable bed. The staff were excellent and very helpful. I would recommend the hotel to anyone visiting this part of Tokyo as it is only a few meters from the subway station.

When thinking about the Tokyu Stay chain, I think affordable quality stay with very simple rooms. This was my first stay at a Japanese-style hotel (as opposed to international chains), and the experience was quite different.The hotel had an almost unbeatable location in Aoyama yet the surrounding was still quiet. If you want shopping in Aoyama or Omotesando, you can't go wrong with this place. It's all you need for a stay without the flair--it's clean, well-serviced, and centrally located.The staff were friendly and spoke fairly good English.Rooms were quite small and my colleagues (two big guys) complained the next morning the bed was quite "fit" too. Admittedly, the bed simply could not compete with the queen-size or king-size beds in the US. Bathroom was basic too.I can't think of much else to say about this place other than its good location and it's clean and sufficient. After all, you get what you pay for and this place is great value for money.

I stayed here from early November until December 21, 2013 and would strongly recommend this hotel to business travelers looking at a comfortable, clean room that they can stay for an extended period of time.I'll start with the things I liked:The room was small but the space was very well-used. I never thought once that I was cramped or claustrophobic. I had room for my laptop and other daily use stuff, books and whatnot. There were chargers everywhere (nice for tech junkies like me) and as long as they are the two prong (non-grounded) you'll be totally fine. The TV was, I'd say, a 32" Toshiba and looked fairly new. The aircon (AC/heating unit) never made me feel cold, hot, stuffy, or damp... it was a Thanksgiving and Christmas miracle! The bathrooms were very clean and the bathtub was very nice to sit in; even me being 6'4 was no issue whatsoever. The room had a kitchen with a hotplate, fridge, denshi range, sink, and cabinets with little pots and pans but I never used them. The location in Aoyama 3 chome was PERFECT for me. It is right next to a supermarket as well as a FamilyMart convenience store. I personally don't enjoy being crowded (Look for my review on the Shibuya Tokyu Stay Excel Hotel) so this location was perfect for me, plus it is only about a 5 minute walk from my office. The staff was very friendly and I'm not sure if they spoke English or not, I try to stick to Japanese just to speed things up a little bit.Let's talk about the things I am not sure some people would like:Their breakfast buffet. I personally loved it. But I will tell you this, it is very very Japanese. They have a nice little salad bar with a good selection of breads and potato salads... then there is the main course. It is really based around a few things: Scrambled eggs (Japanese style is more runny than US kind), rice, grilled or poached salmon or mackerel, natto, miso soup, konnyaku or some type of other traditionally boiled Japanese vegetables or roots, a full selection of delicious juices - literally ANY kind of liquid you would ever think of drinking in the morning, and typically some sort of other specialty from a foreign country (it changed each week from things like pilaf to okonomiyaki to something from Sweden). I love Japanese food so I never thought anything of it but I did watch the faces of other foreigners as they took the plastic cover of a cup of natto and that always made me laugh.I strongly recommend this hotel!

My friend and I stayed at this hotel on our recent holiday in Tokyo and we booked two single rooms. The hotel placed us in adjoining rooms so we had privacy but still felt secure knowing we were separated by a wall. The room was not large but enough space to move around in. This single room is definitely meant for one person only.The bed was excellent for a single bed, it was larger than a super single, and was very firm.It is amazing how many amenities were packed into this little room. As the Chinese saying goes, the pigeon may be tiny but all its internal organs are there. At the desk there is a bar fridge, microwave oven, safe, kettle, hair dryer, and alarm clock. Many power points for these amenities and I can use them as well as charge my phone at the same time. There is another powerpoint near the bed for extra gadgets. The wardrobe had good hangers and more hanging bars by the bed. Two make up mirrors, one on the desk and one on the wall. Outside the bathroom there is another mirror for full length view. By the entrance of the room is a washing machine and a packet of detergent is provided upon check in. There are also two pairs of slippers, one for the room and one for the bathroom. A clean pair of pajamas/yukata is provided daily and towels are changed daily.The bathroom is small but has enough counter space for toiletries. There is even a movable metal bar for hanging laundry. The large bottles of POLA brand shampoo, conditioner and shower gel are placed by the bathtub. Basic toiletries are provide (toothbrush, comb, etc.)The rooms were quiet and I didn't hear my neighbours or any street noises. The location is great with a Dean and Deluca across the street and the Metro is a five minute walk away. Omotesando is another 10 minutes walk from the hotel. Free wifi in the rooms and lobby and breakfast is included. Great Value.

After spending five nights at the Tokyu Stay Aoyama Premier, including waiting out a moderate typhoon that passed over Tokyo on September 16, I can say that I was very pleased / satisfied with my stay. However, there are a few aspects of the hotel that merit consideration before booking. Starting with the positives. The rate I was able to obtain through a third party booking site for a single room in a great Tokyo neighborhood was phenomenal. That one can book a hotel room in the Aoyama district of Tokyo with FREE in-room wi-fi, breakfast included in the room rate, and with a washing machine (includes a drying cycle, so no need for a separate dryer) with nominally priced detergent available at the front desk), and a microwave and refrigerator for less than $125 US per night is amazing. Adding to this is that the wi-fi is very simple to set up and is very stable and sufficiently fast. There is also an in-room safe, and body wash, shampoo, conditioner and hand soap are provided as well. The only negatives on the in-room amenities are that the towels are thin and the toilet paper is not "top of the line." I was in room 2010 and had some road noise, but nothing out of the ordinary. The hotel is near a busy intersection and whenever an ambulance went through, they used a loud speaker to warn cross traffic (great idea, by the way) and that was audible from the room. There are English language instruction pages for the washing machine, the safe and the air conditioner remote control (which you will need, if you are not familiar with typical Japanese hotel a/c set ups). The other overwhelming positive was the neighborhood around the hotel. Excellent choice of dining in all cuisines. There are several restaurants in the Aoyama Passage at the foot of the hotel. I found a Britsh Pub on the road to Meiji Jingu Stadium (less than 10 minute walk from the hotel). There are two Starbucks within five minutes of the hotel, and three more on the walk to Shibuya Station (not to mention the world's busiest Starbucks at Hachinko Crossing outside Shibuya Station). There is a Family Mart around the corner and a 7-11 across Aoyama Dori. There is also easy access to the Gaiemmae Station (G-03) on the Ginza Line. More on that below.Two aspects that I would consider positive but not to the same degree as above. I found the hotel staff to be helpful and polite (and English speaking) but the overall level of common area amenities was sparse (one vending machine, hidden just off the check in lobby on the 13th floor). One pays for one's stay at check-in. Breakfast is in the Architect Cafe in the same building on the second floor (so outside of the hotel area which is floors 13-25). At check in, one is given coupons for breakfast, otherwise the charge is 1,200 yen. Note, bring the coupon with you. Your room card / your room number means zip / zilch / nada to the Cafe crew. The cafe has sufficient seating, but is overall a bit cramped (not a lot of "personal space"). The selection of food is OK, but may feel limited to those with western preferences. There is a good selection of beverages, including - for breakast - iced black tea, iced oolong tea, and iced coffee. Of the three differenent hotels I've stayed at in Tokyo over the years, while the this hotel is the least expensive, the breakfast is also the most limited. Of course, it is included in the room rate.The one negative is the size of the room. Single A guest rooms are described on the hotel's website as 17 m2. That is about 185 square feet. There is no room to spare and the room felt cramped. It rained hard on September 15 in the morning and then Typhoon TS 1318 passed over on the 16th, and I was most glad to be able to get out of the room when the weather cleared in the afternoon both days. A few suggestions / observations for guests planning on booking a stay.1) The hotel has an excellent website. Search for "Tokyu Stay Aoyama Premier" and you should easily find a link to an English language version of the hotel's website. Check this out before booking.2) The hotel is intended as an "extended stay" hotel. If you are staying more than six nights, be sure you understand the hotel's room servicing policies.3) The hotel is the tallest building in the neighborhood, and the elevator lobbies have good views of the Shinjuku highrise district and rooms xx07-xx16 (at least that is the case on the 20th floor) have views of Mt. Fuji and the hills west of Tokyo on clear days. I would imagine the views of central Tokyo from east facing rooms are equally good.4) This hotel has very easy access to the Gaiemmae station (G-03) on the Ginza Line. Enter and exit via Gate 1A and you will be within a two - three minute walk of the hotel entrance. I have been in Tokyo previously, and had tried (wisely) to avoid Tokyo subways at peak hours. I did not have a choice this time on two occasions and misjudged the end of morning rush hour on another occasion. The Ginza Line gets quite crowded at peak hours - and that is an understatement. The most crowded stretch is between stops G-05 (Akasaka - Mitsuke) and G-08 (Shimbashi). However, crowding can extend all the way to Shibuya (G-01) through Nihombashi (G-11). Just be forewarned, because unless you are willing to walk a bit, your "first kilometre" and "last kilometre" of public transit access to and from this hotel are going to be on the Ginza Line. Also, Gaiemmae is the station for the Yakult Swallows stadium and the national rugby stadium. I did not use the station during peak crowd arrival or departure times, but I imagine it can get hectic. Otherwise, I found it a fairly quiet, easy to navigate station. Overall, I think this is a great value in Tokyo lodging with a lot of positives. But do consider room sizes, servicing on longer stays and the subway access before booking.

This hotel is really nice for a short term stay in Tokyo for non-Japanese looking for a place that is less expensive than the 5 start hotels. . It is excellent value and provides the best breakfast buffet for foreigners outside of the 5 star hotels. This is generally my hotel of choice when I travel to Japan as it is Central and convenient to my work place. The staff are conscientious as is the case always in Japan. The rooms are quite small as is also the norm in Japan but the work space is adequate to spread out a computer and there is also room to hang suits. Most of the necesssary information is in English. The one difficult thing about this hotel is that you will need to get a cab from wherever you get off the bus from Narita/Haneda.

Stayed here b/c I missed my train back home which takes like 20000yen. Excellent location, great neighborhood (very quiet). Great staff and interior.But very small room size for what you pay for. I would stay here again if I had extra $$.

Really nice hotel, perfect location, good price for value and beautiful view over Tokyo. All in all really recommended if you're staying in Tokyo, want a central location in an quiet neighbourhood and want to combine business with leasure.

I flew in to Narita Airport and took the bus (Limousine?) to Tokyo. While the 1 hr. bus did no go directly to my hotel, I selected a bus that got me close (within 1.5 miles) and took a cab to my hotel. I purchased a ticket to the Excel? Hotel figuring that was closest to my hotel. It was the 3rd or 4th stop and it would have been better to get off at the Osio? Hotel (1st stop) and take a cab from there. That move would have saved 20-30 minutes as the bus dropped other off others at these hotels. The Tokyu Stay Aoyama Premier is a small hotel and the taxi driver had to enter the address in his GPS to find it.The lobby for the hotel is on the 12th floor and rooms are above that floor. I did not need help with getting bags to my room, and there did not appear to be anyone to help if needed. The staff spoke very good English and they were very helpful. I received a breakfast coupon for each night that allowed me to eat each morning at a small restaurant on the 2nd floor. The food was mostly Japanese with some western food and the restaurant staff was very helpful. Unfortunately there was no coffee only tea, so a quick trip around the corner to Starbucks was needed. I never felt unsafe walking around.The room was very “efficient” and typical for many Tokyo hotels. The main room was 8’ x 8’ wall to wall. There was ~2’ of floor at the end of the bed about ~3’ on the side. The fire escape map confirmed that all rooms on that floor (21st) were the same size. I did have a view of Mt. Fuji one morning, but most of the time it was hidden by clouds (smog?). The bed was very firm and the pillows were also stiff/firm. There were no drawers to use for unpacking your bag. The small slot (6” wide) to hang up clothes could only fit 3 hangers. There was a microwave, very small frig and washing machine in the room. The hotel was very quiet and I didn’t hear any noises from the adjacent rooms. The lighting was controlled by buttons on the headboard and there was a nice “Night Light” that provided dim light to find the bathroom. There was a cut out in the headboard to hold your iPhone and a power outlet next to it if you use the phone as an alarm clock. The heated bathroom seat is typical for Tokyo. The tub walls were quite high and the hand held shower fit nicely into a high bracket for a typical US shower experience. The room had a good size personal safe that allowed me to lock up my laptop and other valuables. The free Wi-Fi was very strong and Skype to the US worked very smoothly. The AC unit is mounted above the headboard on the wall and worked fine once I found the English instructions in the book on the desk.The room was very clean, and I will go back to this hotel again.

This is the perfect base for any traveller. Clean, good sized rooms complete with washer/drier, microwave and cooking faciliities. Wifi now in every room. A very easy 2 stops from Shibuya and 2 minutes from the subway station. You can walk to Shibuya in about 20 minutes and if you go right at the Omotesando subway, a direct road takes you down to Meigi Jingu shrine and Harajuku. As a female travelling alone the whole area feels very safe to walk around at any time. Very good transport connections to other parts of Tokyo. Excellent breakfasts so you can fill up for the day. Good range of eating places close by, both Japanese and European. Try Eat on Kita-Aoyama for a cheap tasty burger. Lovely cake shop down stairs. Staff are pleasant and helpful. My only quibble would be the twit that decided to do his washing at midnight. Great views of Tokyo.

Tokyu Stay Aoyama Premier is located in the Aoyama district, the most fashionable part of Tokyo and only 2 minutes walk to Tokyo Metro Ginza line Gaienmae station.Also close to Akasaka business district, Harajyuku fashion town, and Shibuya.The rooms are equipped with washing machine, mini kitchen, presser and complimentary buffet breakfast in one of their tenant cafe.They also have serviced apartments for longer stays.Jingu Gaien park is nearby if you want to go jogging,or lots of top-notch restaurants which Aoyama is famous for.The staffs are welcoming but the service is limited as this hotel is regarded as business hotel,and not a luxury hotel. But that's what keeps the price down.Lots of Western people live in Aoyama too, which makes this place distinguished.

I chose this hotel based on reviews in Tripadvisor for location, views, cleanliness and value for money. The hotel lived up to my expectations. My conference was at the United Nations University which is closer to Shibuya but still walkable frorm this hotel - 15 mins brisk walk or 20 minutes at a relaxed pace. I chose the smaller configuration room (listed as 'A' on website - 17m square) and it was adequate for my needs as a single guest. If you have lots of luggage or plan to spend a lot of time at the hotel or you want to do in room work-outs, yoga or whatever then you would find this room cramped. But if you want to use this as a base for conferences, explore sites, go shopping, jogging etc and return to admire the view and rest then this hotel is well suited. You can walk to Meiji Shrine and surrounding park. I paid a small surchage for a room with a view and I could see Mt Fuji from my window, depending on cloud cover. Also, I was offered a discount for booking around 3 weeks in advance. The breakfast was fine. The room had a reverse cycle split system air con which worked well but took a few attempts to adjust the settings appropriate to my needs. The room was very quiet. The pillow was firm which suited me fine.There was a vent in the window sill to let in a bit of extra air and street sound if you like. There was wi-fi in the room for no extra charge.

I stay at this hotel every time I visit Tokyo. Considering the prime location (it's like 5th Avenue in NYC), the rates are amazingly low. The rates also includes excellent breakfast buffet which otherwise would cost you $15 or so. It's 2 minutes walk to a subway station and you can walk to Omotesando, Harajuku, and Akasaka. It's also a great location for a runner. I run every morning to Akasaka Gyoen. It's one of the prime jogging course in Japan. The rooms are small, but has everything you need. A free Wifi connection, a small fridge, a microwave, and a washer/dryer. A washer/dyer in each room! That's the best feature as far as I'm considered. Last time I was in Tokyo, I stayed this hotel 16 days and I was so glad I could do laundry every the other day.I give 5 stars to this hotel not because of its' service or beauty. For the location, convenience, and rates, this is simply the best choice for a long stay. You can trust me because I used to live in Tokyo.

I stay at this hotel whenever I come to Tokyo on business because my customer has a negotiated rate with this hotel. Hotels can be expensive in Tokyo, and the rate I am charged at this hotel is quite low in comparison with others. The hotel is located in the Aoyama section of Tokyo near a number of restaurants and stores. It is a very nice area, and I enjoy walking around the neighborhood in the evening after work. The hotel is conveniently located just around the corner from the Gaiemmae Station on the Ginza Line (Stop G03). Getting from either Haneda or Narita Airports is fairly easy. Both airports have trains into the city with Metro connections. From there, it is a simple matter of getting on the Ginza Line.As for the room itself, it is small. This is Tokyo, and the rooms in this hotel are actually not small by Tokyo standards. Not that I want to spend all my time indoors watching TV, but the lack of channels in any language other than Japanese is a bit of a disappointment. They have CNN, but they often dub over the English with Japanese except at night. They have a way of ordering movies on the TV, but I was not interested and did not take the time to figure out how to do so.My stay included internet access and breakfast. Internet speed is good, but access is via ethernet cable in the rooms and wifi in the lobby. The rooms do not have wifi. The breakfast is a bit of a job just to be completely honest. The selection is poor and not particularly tasty.The rooms are clean, conveniently located, and are offered at a good price. If this is what you need, then this is the place for you. If you are looking for more than that, you may want to look elsewhere.

Rooms on the small side but nice, clean and comfortable. Internet access in the room is only via a cable near the tv stand and free wifi in the lobby downstairs. Views are great and the breakfast is a mix of Asian and continental.

I'm entering my third week at this Tokyu Stay, and it feels like home. Like other travelers have mentioned, the room is on the small side, but normal for Tokyo and comfortable for one. It has a small fridge with freezer, kettle, hot pad, and most importantly for a multi-week stay: a washer/dryer combo tucked by the door. Other hotels have seemingly larger rooms, but the floor space here is used for these extras that make a long stay away from home bearable. There are cubbies to store things everywhere.The staff speaks perfect English and goes out of their way to be helpful. They sell little things you might need in the room - like a pack of laundry detergent for 30 yen. The hotel is almost right on the Ginza line, which is an easy way to go most places in Tokyo. A word of warning - the Ginza line is PACKED during commute hours. This neighborhood is quiet for Tokyo: there's not that much in the area itself, but Omato-sando is only a 10-minute walk away. For the Americans here, the ATM at the post office right around the corner will be great to have, since most ATMs here don't take our credit cards. There's also a convenience store, grocery store, and at least 15 restaurants within a 3 minute walk. Like I said, quiet for Tokyo.Being the only high building on its block, you do get great views. One side of the hotel faces Mt. Fuji (in the distance, but pretty cool to see) and the other side faces the giant Oracle building, a cemetery, and the green spaces of a large park. On the ladies only floor, the rooms type B (larger rooms with kitchenette) face Oracle and gets the sunrise sun, type A face Mt. Fuji and I assume gets sunset sun in the room. The curtains are heavy but not blackout curtains. At night there's baseball games in the school field below, and it's fun to watch the little people run around. Weird thing about reservations: when you reserve on their web site they don't ask for your credit card. The web reservation system is a little convoluted, but it is in English. When you show up and check in, they charge you for your entire stay.Breakfast is decent and the little croissants are delish. I'm glad I read the other reviews and brought my own squishy pillow: they do have Japanese pillows here. Next time I'm in Tokyo I'll stay here again.

I chose this hotel for its location on my visit back home because it's very close to where I was born and lived till my departure for the US long time ago. So I am very familiar with the area. The hotel is a few minutes walk from Gaienmae Station on Tokyo's oldest subwayGinza (orange) Line It is very convenient to get to many major spots inTokyo on this line such as Shibuya, the Imperial Palace and Japan's National Government area, Akihabara, Ueno and Asakusa. There are two local bus routs to Shibuya through now famous highends shopping district of Omotesando and Roppongi. The bus stop is right around the corner from the hotel. Although we can walk to Omotesando and Shibuya the bus service was handy. The hotel also is very close to Meiji Shrine, Takeshitacho, Meiji Outer Garden with the National track and field stadium (1964 Tokyo Olympic major stadium) and two baseball parks. Shinjuku and other areas are also easy to get to by transfer to other lines, The area is full of modern shops and restaurants. A super market Peacock is relatively next door. Also a post office where we can use ATM is very close.The hotel occupies the 13th where the lobby is to the top floor(26th?). The guests get to the necessary floors by using room cards on the elevator so it's very secure. Since it is relatively new the facility is very modern. My room on the 22nd foor was exclusively for ladies. The room is equipped with everything we need, a fridge, a microwave oven, a set of dishes, a trouser press and a washer-dryer combo. My room faced the West toward Aoyama and Shibuya. Mt. Fuji can be seen on fine days. From the hallway window we can see Shinjuku highrises and all the way to the right Tokyo's newest attraction "Tokyo Sky Tree" was visible. Fom the lobby we can see other directions including Tokyo Tower. The room is not large but it has a good size (Queen size) bed and it was big enough for me. The front desk staff was polite and helpful. They kept my luggage for a day without any fuss.My plan included breakfast which is served on the 2nd floor "Architect Cafe"/ It is a combination of Japanese and Western style buffet but more on Japanese side. It could be richer in varieties but it was sufficient.Overall I rate this hotel excellent. It is perfect for shopping and sight seeing. The only thing is that it is rather on the higher price bracket for a "business hotel".I enjoyed my five days very much and I especially enjoyed the views from the hotel. I was greeted with the stunningly beautiful night view when I returned to my room at night.I'd like to thank all the hotel staff for making my stay comfortable and enjoyable.I regret I couldn't stay longer.

This hotel is very conveniently located with many boutique shops (for many well known brands like Coach, Louis Vuitton, and Prada) nearby. There are also many restaurants in the area. My room was on the 25th Floor and had a spectacular view of Mt. Fuji. The hotel does not appear to have bellmen, which is very unusual for Japan. The staff at the desk is less helpful than other Japanese hotels. Breakfast selection was limited and tended towards more Japanese norms. There were 4 pillows on the double bed. 2 were buckwheat. The other 2 were this odd gelatin-like compound. The bathtub was quite narrow and the shower head had a rather narrow stream. This hotels seems like it is more focused on Japanese travellers and less on Western travellers.
Bit more expensive than the standard Tokyo "business hotel" but nice decor, unbostructed views (can see Mt Fuji from west facing rooms in winter) and terrific Aoyama location make it worthwhile.

As luck would have it, we were given a room on the top floor facing Mt Fuji. We woke up to an amazing panorama of Tokyo each morning! The room was a decent size that didn't make us feel claustrophobic, and there was a combo washer/dryer for longer stays. We did not see instructions in English, so you will probably need to ask staff for help if you need to use it. The hotel was located very close to the metro in a ritzy neighborhood. I liked that the lobby was on another floor so that staff didn't watch your comings and goings as is usual in other places. Breakfast was included with the room and was served buffet style (had a mixture of Japanese and American options). Definitely a good value!
user_name:
JKnyc
New York City, New York

review_body: The location is unbeatable - really. I have been to Tokyo maybe 100 times as I travel there every 6-8 weeks. I love the Aoyoyama/Harjuku neighborhood where Tokyustay Aoyama is. In a crowded, often ugly city it is really a livable place. The hotel is new and the rooms are spotless. The views can be beautiful as well with a view of Fuji on one side of the hotel when weather permits.However, I refer to my room at Tokyustay as "The Cell". It is exactly like a prison cell in size and configuration. That's just how I feel staying there - like I am in prison. A small desk at the end of the room, a tiny bathroom, a small bed with incredibly hard pillows. With all the Westerners there, I would think they would provide a decent pillow. A carefully rationed towel with that isn't soft, cozy or absorbent. There is a small fridge, tiny microwave, and a hot plate. But, I am an adult, I don't hot plate my dinners from $3 grocery store packages.If you are on the east facing side about three hours after the sun rises, the sun will bake the room so much you have to close the blind. A room that size heats up like an oven - fast. And with the blind closed the prison cell experience is complete.It's cheap folks - you decide.There is a washer and dryer in the

Don't expect too much. The rooms are small, standard equipment, but nothing really to complain about. Internet is free, TV channels are only Japanese. Location is good even though you are not really in the heart of the action. Wouldn't mind to stay again but also wouldn't mind to stay somewhere else. Breakfast is a buffet in a public cafe. OK, but also nothing exciting.

If you are in Tokyo for the first time, it's a MUST to stay in this hotel, it's surely price for value, no regrets at all. It's geographically centralized to get to almost all the tourist attraction areas: bars, restaurants and shopping malls. The Architect Cafe every morning serves simple but very delicious authentic Japanese cuisines.Remember overall it's a sure MUST try experience.

This hotel worked well for us even though we had to get 2 rooms. It's main feature for us was it's location in Aoyama which was central to all the places we wanted to get to in Tokyo.The room is small, but it has good amenities like a fridge and hotplate, a bidet (I WANT one now!) and whatever soap they're using is fantastic! They also have both memory foam AND husk pillows and the sheets must be a very high thread count.The only "problem" I had was using the free internet in the lobby. It has a Japanese/English keyboard and the punctuation is not always in keeping with the English board which made it difficult to enter my password. Not all of the staff is techno-savvy but they tried their best to help, but after a while I gave up.The breakfast buffet is fantastic and has both Western and Japanese fare. I think for the money it's quite a value.

this is a relatively new hotel. Just a short, two-minute walk from Gaienmae Station- there are many little streets lined with shops nearby. stayed in a single room. tried to check-in early, but they strictly adhere to the 3pm check-in time, even if there are rooms available! rooms are simple and clean.breakfast is provided at architect cafe below at 2/f, with a simple buffet. there are restaurants below with an english menu, and a small supermarket too. they are not too used to foreigners here- i saw mostly japanese visitors during my stay.
